												BlazeRush is one of the games you get in a bundle, activate the key, idle the cards and leave it in your library to collect dust, but trust me this game needs to played by everyone who like arcadey top down racing games.BlazeRush is about racers who like racing (great story right ?) and there's a corporation that tries to stop them racing by taking over every planet they race in.Of course you are not in it for the story and for the gameplay and let me tell you it's quite a treat.There are  main events and I'll go through each one. The regular races where you need to finish first and try not to get destroyed by the enemy drivers, king of the hill where you try to stay in the lead for 50 seconds and a deathmatch where there's a steam roller behind you and you try to be the final person alive, a time trial mode where you need to finish a lap in a certain amount of time and there's a boss battle in the final mission where you need to use the weapons you used in the game to destroy the "Boss". Each of these events are very chaotic and they are incredibly difficult so don't expect to breeze through all the events. The enemy AI is violent and every chance they get they will take you out and trust me you need to play dirty to win.The soundtrack is really great as well and is awesome to listen to when you are playing this game.The graphics are alright for the most part, and I love the cell shaded look for the tracks. The track designs range from mediocre to pretty good. Each track has certain points where you can jump out of the track if you use boosters, but those parts are marked on the map, but it's still sometimes frustrating.Now for the bad things for the game:The one thing I hated was the fact that when you die you are set back so far back that there is almost no point in competing and the only solution is to restart.The controls if you are using a keyboard takes a lot of time getting used to and I highly HIGHLY recommend using a controller.The difficulty comes off as really difficult even in the early stages and not to mention the final act in the volcano planet has a massive difficulty spike and the final boss is quite tough, so be prepared for a challenge.The camera is atrocious, it only follows the leading car at all times so if you are too far behind and too far ahead you will have to use the map to navigate the entire map.Overall BlazeRush is a really fun game and it's pretty difficult as well, while I don't think it's worth the full price, it's worth it if it's in a bundle or on a discount.Final Rating:7/10 - Worth checking outIf you liked this review please consider giving it a thumbs up and if you disliked post in the comments on what you disliked about this review.For more reviews follow Snort's Review curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

												There are LOTS of “over the top” racing games available. Some have better physics or realistic tracks, some have more versatile and adaptable camera angles, and some have better soundtracks.But “BlazeRush” has a remarkable combination of variety of tracks, outrageous quantity of awards (and a great points system), and just LOTS of quick, repeatable fun with a wide choice of cars to make every race as different as one might wish. I don’t know about multiplayer yet, but I suspect that’s where “BlazeRush” really shines. But what I love? The really cool achievements, a third of which are cumulative. This type of short race game can become a bit tedious, but with so much variety as to cars, weapons, tracks, physics (such as different planets), this won’t happen any time soon. Currently I have about a dozen tracks that I’ve managed to unlock that I haven’t had time to even examine yet. And numerous untried cars as well.As a player with a “bad” left hand, I generally have to be cautious when I buy any driving game (especially expensive ones.) No problem here, except for hand fatigue, as with any controller (or keyboard) game requiring both hands to play. The controls work very well, even when they’re not meant to (as in certain types of tracks or deliberate cool physics gimmicks.) The menus are simple, yet adequate and seem to be anything a player might ask for. Graphics aren’t exactly Earth-shaking, but are in no way lacking. Really, my only issue so far is that the camera seems to follow the lead cars, and a trailing driver may find themself off the screen entirely. (But unlikely for more than a few seconds.) A car leaving the track entirely will find themselves returned, but at a small loss to position.I’ll make every attempt to come back when I have more to say, but if you have REMARKABLY little to spend (for a few more days, at least), I think most people will be very happy adding “BlazeRush” to their collection of FUN OTT racing games.Thank you.

												The racing genre has retained its popularity after many years, but nowadays most titles offer the regular recipe of driving from a realistic perspective, using behind the car, cockpit, or "first-person" views. Even so, there are still those who prefer isometric experiences that hark back to the early days of the games industry.BlazeRush is an example of such a modernized experience, as developer Targem Games wants to offer an isometric racing game that's fun, fast, and balanced with a wide array of abilities and bonuses, not to mention varied vehicles with advantages and disadvantages.Even if most racing games nowadays abandon any semblance of a story, BlazeRush still has a single-player campaign that offers a bit of background on the game's universe, its characters, and more. It doesn't take itself seriously, thankfully, and just uses a bit of reasoning to promote a more eco-friendly message, not to mention one against evil corporations.Of course, one of the most important things in BlazeRush is the gameplay. The action takes place on different circuits across multiple environments. You race against a different number of opponents each time and the goal is to ensure you score trophies, which then unlock new stages and events.The actual racing mechanics feel pretty good, but it's important to note that you can only control your vehicle with the analog stick on the controller or the keyboard keys. There's no acceleration or braking, so it might take some time to get used to BlazeRush.Things get a bit more complex as you progress through the campaign, as the circuits are filled with portions that don't have any guard rails, not to mention tight corners and ramps that, when taken with extra speed, can propel you outside the track's bounds.Besides the intense racing experience, the game also features different weapons and speed bonuses that drop onto the circuit from above in a chaotic manner. The weapons range from a minigun to a sawblade launcher, a guided missile, a goo ball that can slow your ride, and much more.The game also drops behind the leader crates with speed bonuses. These range from a lengthy but moderate speed increase to rocket tubes that provide short but powerful boosts, fans that work when you don't make sudden turns, and other such things.In terms of race types, there are quite a few interesting ones. Of course, as always, there are lap-based events where crossing the finish line first is the only thing that matters. There are also King of the Hill-type races where you need to stay in front of the pack for a total of 50 seconds. The most hectic, however, is the Death Race type, in which a giant steamroller barrels down the track towards the competing cars.Many crazy trophies are awarded at the end of the race for all sorts of feats you manage during the actual event. From seizing or losing victory in the final meters to unleashing crazy weapons and perfect boosts, they are rewarded with hilarious mentions.Vehicle variety is pretty solid, with each car/ship boasting three core stats, in the form of mass, acceleration, and handling.While BlazeRush manages to deliver a solid racing experience, it does get a bit frustrating when you're stuck in the back of the pack, as the game teleports you in order to keep up with others. This can get confusing quite fast. It also doesn't do that good of a job when it comes to highlighting your own vehicle. If the cars are grouped up and the same model is used by an AI, you can easily lose sight of your ride.BlazeRush looks decent but it's clear that Targem emphasizes framerate over pretty graphics. The game maintains a really fast framerate at all times, no matter how hectic the action might get. The cars and the tracks also look pretty good but the surrounding environments aren't that impressive.The soundtrack is instrumental only and features quite a bit of dubstep, house, or techno tracks. It matches the action on the screen quite well, so you'll certainly enjoy it.BlazeRush is a really fun isometric arcade racing experience that manages to deliver explosive action, imaginative weapons, and balanced speed boosts to create an addictive flow

												Local co-op, check. Local co-op + can play online, check. Immersive and exciting game, check. Blaze rush is an action racing thriller designed to test your Mario Kart capabilities from an angled top down view. For something so simple, the game is ensured to keep you coming back to play again and again. BlazeRush is a violent racing game with extremely simplistic racing controls. There is no specific button to break as acceleration is achieved by moving the left joystick in the direction you'd like to go. There is an arrow drawn to indicate which way you are pointing the joystick. Three main attributes are given to the vehicles which are mass, acceleration, and handle-ability. The three are self explanatory but depending on how you like to play (dangerous vs pre-cautious) will determine which vehicle you choose. Each vehicle is made with a different purpose.  Some are tank like and slow, but are heavy and hard to knock around. Some are hover vehicles and are quite fast, but fly easily when they get hit. The hover vehicles feel like the dominant ones to me but I have noticed online four wheelers are the go to choice. Once you choose a vehicle, it's time to choose a race type. In King of the Hill, the winning player simply has to hold the lead. Deathmatch requires you to be first again however there is a giant steam rolling chasing behind you. Fail to keep up or stay ahead and you'll soon be squashed. This game mode is the best one in my opinion as it's last person standing. The last game mode is racing, where obviously the goal is to come first at the end of doing a set amount of laps. Players are able to choose game type and map when starting a game and after completing a game. This sort of UI keeps everything running smooth jumping from event to event. Playing local co-op mixed in with a few people from online adds another dimension to the game AI's couldn't do. It is extremely funny to come across different play styles of gamers that race online. None the less though, I've seen the AI's take some crazy risks that I would consider absurd. Usually, they play it safe by toeing the line but I've caught a few AI's trying to jump ramps and even over turns to beat me. There aren't numerous power ups like Mario Kart but the essential ones feel there. There are two main power up types, nitro based and weapon based. Nitro based are different as some will provide quick acceleration for a short period of time while some are gradual acceleration over a longer period of time. Weapons come in the form of bioacid that slows the player down, a Star Wars looking plate dish push force, machine gun that fires numerous times, a homing missile that slowly closes in on the target in front of you, and a saw blade that spins vehicles out of control. Power up drops are consistent throughout events. Graphics and design are completely suitable to the atmosphere and game play surrounding BlazeRush. The tires bounce appropriately and the collisions feel excellent. Only complaint is when turning into someone at the start, it doesn't feel as though you can steer them off course by pushing them. It does work when the game picks up and the speeds are different but can feel awkward when first starting a race. Explosions are well done and re spawn graphics and times are excellent. There is even a horn that sounds in deathmatch when the steam roller begins it's speed tirade. Sounds are graphics deliver exactly what they are meant to bring, excitement and suspense when spinning out of control.I would highly recommend this game on everyone's library, for a good sale price of course :). For the full price I bought four copies of the games, so may not be a bad idea to wait. The fact that you can play local co-op and play online simply shows these guys care. Even if you don't have a buddy to play with, the single player campaign will satisfy your one player needs before jumping online to cause some havoc. Everything seems like it was done right here and done with proper attention and care. For future development perhaps add more weapons and game modes? Maybe even add something that disrupts the terrain? There are some cool maps that were designed, would be nice to maybe integrate them with the attacks. Player two even gets a vote Character selection screen with the three attributes displayed in 2 player mode Local co-op with someone about to go the wrong way They made it extremely easy to add more players to the game (up to four). 												I have a lot of these "mini racers" or "top down racers" now, both combat (Burning Cars, Death Rally) and non-combat (Bang Bang Racing, MiniMotor EVO, Little Racers Street, Real World Racing), and while I have only gotten into a few of them, I think I have seen enough of Blazerush to say that it's the best one on Steam. The controls feel spot-on from the moment you begin, and they even feel pretty good with the keyboard. Works well with Xbox360 controller, does not work with directinput gamepad. Acceleration with the 360 controller is "push in the direction to move" instead of say a throttle trigger or button, which felt odd at first, but I quickly grew to like it. There are a lot of cars to choose from, all with a cool sort of Micromachines-meets-MadMax type of style. They have only 3 attributes each (acceleration, mass, and handling) but some feel different based on their wheel config (two or 4 wheels, tracked, hover, etc). There seems to be plenty of tracks to unlock, with quite a few different themes, but maybe too many of them have the same "wasteland" feel to them.  I know it's supposed to be that way, but it actually makes some of the tracks too similar. Amazon and the snow ones are nice standouts. The main drawback to the game as I have seen (only a few hours played so far) is the lack of upgrades & customization for the vehicles - there are none. No skins, no engine or weapon upgrades to buy, no garage to manage, the only thing to do in this game is pick a car and race. Not a big deal but it is a bit one-dimensional. The game could definitely use more weapons as well,  so far have autogun, saw, missle, slime, & sonic; perhaps I haven't unlocked them all yet, but I havent seen any others in any screenshots. In quite a few ways this game reminded me of Cel Damage, with the wild comebacks and last-second heroics, or knowing you were blasted off the track to oblivion but getting in that last perfectly-aimed kill as you fall down a cliff. It could have taken another page from Cel Damage by including more weapons, and my number one request would be a mode where you choose exactly which powerups are available in a given skirmish race. In other words, maybe you feel like all rocket boosters and buzz saws, so you could make it so only those populate in that race. The game runs at like 300 frames per second, which ran too hot for my gpu, but it has it's own FPS limiter in the options*, so I won't have to remember to change my fps limit manually on my gpu every time I play. Nice! *for some reason when I limit the game to 120 fps, it runs at 111 fps. When I had used my gpu's limiter, I ran at 90 fps and it ran 90, idk why the in-game limiter runs different but it doesnt matter much). The one time I went to play multiplayer, it was a lot of fun but only one round was going on, with about 6-8 people playing. It was a little bit laggy but very fun. All in all, I really enjoy this game, and the mix of challenge vs casual fun seems about right. A good choice if you are looking for a top down mini racer, even without a sale price.

IntroductionBlazeRush is a third-person perspective, arcade racer that combines simple controls with brilliant physics resulting in one hell of a good time. This is the type of game that you may look at and ignore, or you obtain it somehow and let it sit in your library. Well let me just say that BlazeRush is worth your time and money, here's why.GameplayBlazeRush is a primarily single-stick controlled game with power-ups. Think of Mario Kart but at a fixed camera angle and without any real complex driving mechanics whatsoever. Simply point the controller stick in the direction you wish to go, and your vehicle will go in that direction (also indicated by an arrow at the front of the vehicle). I'll say it now that this game requires a controller for precision; I would not recommend using KB+M for it. Now, you may not be into that sort of thing, that's fine. However, neither am I, yet this game managed to actually capture my attention on multiple occasions. Power-upsThanks to power-ups, it turns a pretty standard game into one hell of an explosive, speed-fest. From rocket boosts, to actual (semi) heat-seeking rockets, racing and combat collide in a desperate struggle for first-place. Just as power-ups make Mario Kart highly entertaining, power-ups are absolutely amazing in BlazeRush. The system for obtaining them is also a bit unique. Items simply fall from the sky at random, and people can drive into them to collect them. They fall a lot more frequently for the people further behind the leaders but leaders can continue to collect items that they may need in the future to maintain that lead.Catch-upNow due to the fixed camera angle, obviously some cars may fall too far behind and then no longer be visible. As a result, there is an automatic catch-up system in the game. Fall too far behind and the game will automatically move you close enough to the rest of the racers without giving you any advantages. The system here feels fluid and balanced and never takes away from the flow of the game. VehiclesEach type of vehicle has their own strengths and weaknesses. Tank-type vehicles will do excellently on cornering, but drifting is horrible on them, and their top speed is pretty limited. Racing-type vehicles are great at speed in all aspects, and can drift, but their handling is pretty weak and can easily be pushed out of the stage with various weapons. Flying-type vehicles are a bit balanced in most aspects but don't expect them to shine in any particular aspect.CampaignThe campaign is one of the best ways to actually get into this game. Levels progress in difficulty slowly, introducing you to different environments, weapons, vehicles and power-ups. The AI provides a healthy challenge while not being too over-the-top or rage inducing.VisualsThe graphics of BlazeRush are well designed and attractive, combining a semi-cartoony look with over-the-top explosions for an insanely fun experience. AudioVehicle sounds, weapons, power-ups and other elements of the game sound very good and really give the right effect at the right time. The soundtrack is fairly well varied and entertaining. For an arcade game such as this, it felt right at home.Summary & ConclusionI didn't expect much from BlazeRush but after playing it on so many occasions I have to admit it is quite fun and addicting. It's even more so playing with other people, but the campaign is highly challenging and worth playing too. I'm quite impressed that this game has captivated my interest this much and I would highly recommend it to anyone who likes arcade racers in general.8/10 - Friendships will be destroyed this dayIf you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. 												BlazeRush is an arcade style race-battle game designed to keep everyone in the race as much as possible.  The balance is just right to reward skill but to also allow a little luck to pop in now and then.  The game supports both single-player and mutli-player.  And it does not short change the single-player mode as it contains many maps/levels and includes a final boss battle.The controls are slick and the motion could be described as having exaggerated physics.  Note that some people in the reviews here have complained about the controls as the car moves in the direction you point your controller which is not standard in overhead race games.  It took me a few races to get used to it and then it felt quite natural.  Another popular complaint from reviewers is that when your car falls too far behind or goes off the track, the game advances your car to the end of the pack.  Some do not like this "catch up" feature but I find this feature keeps the race exciting.There are three race modes -- normal, leader of the pack, and out run the grinder.  Leader of the pack requires a racer to be in the front for a total of 50 seconds.  Out running the grinder is my favorite as it involves a giant grinding machine chasing the racers.  This mode will keep you on the edge of your seat as an unstoppable monster nips at your bumper.  All three race modes have random power-ups that fall onto the track such as weapons and speed boosts.  The speeds boosts though only fall to the car not in first place thus once again causing exciting lead changes in this game.Get this game if you enjoy the fun of back-and-forth battle-oriented races.  It's a little gem!

The best mode in my opinion is Death race, where you're chased by a giant tank that will destroy you if you linger to much behind. You're forced to go forward, but being too much forward leaves you at the mercy of your opponents. There are 16 vehicles available with different statistics (Top speed is the same for everyone) : Acceleration, weight, control. You will find 5-6 different weapons et 3 types of boosts. One good point is that each enhancement is displayed on the car, which permits you to see immediatly if your opponent has a dangerous weapon without looking at the HUD.   Pros  Good controls A variety of vehicles, but quite balanced Many weapons, but no mario blue shell. Each weapon is deadly, but you can react to them.  Easy to join a game : Plug a controller, press start, your car appears immediatly. Decent netcode for online games FUN ! 												One of the best VR (Oculus Rift) compatible games in my library. This is such a fun and simple game. The controls are really easy to learn, since you only have to steer, shoot, and use a nitro boost. The gameplay isn't exactly the most original in the world, but it takes all of your favorite tabletop racing games from the past and adds a ton of polish, solid controls, and plenty of fun modes to choose from.If you have ever played Mashed (Drive to Survive), Micro Machines, Rock n' Roll Racing, RC Pro AM, or anything similar, then you will feel right at home. Using an Oculus Rift with this is so good it gives you an advantage, since you can look around the track to see upcoming turns and threats more easily. When playing in VR, it makes you feel like you are playing with remote control cars and sitting right next to the track. VR doesn't have to be in first person, and this is an awesome example of how anything can work with it.My only gripe is the compatibility with Oculus Rift is a tad clunky to configure. You have to set the Oculus Rift to "Extended Mode" in your settings and set your headset as "primary display" in your Windows display setting. Once you do that you will be good to go. Definitely pick this up if you get a chance, this game is a blast to play online and it even supports local multiplayer.

Pure malicious glee! - 7/10Introduction:BlazeRush looks like your typical Rock'n Roll Racing, Micro Machines, Bang Bang Racing (and so on..) clone at first glance, but it shines out with its own unique gameplay. The main goal in BlazeRush is to get 1st place like in most racing games. Yet, the main focus (and the fun) of the game relies entirely on the destruction of your opponents. All players share the same camera view and the player field is forced to be in this area of view, which leads to a always dense player field with nonstop action. If you fall behind too much, then you will be always teleported to the end of the current camera view. You can reach place 1 from the last place in seconds and the other way around. This way no one can be lapped, but this could be a no-go for any serious die-hard racer. It was a good design decision in my opinion, because it allows the game to shine with its main focus and strength: the battles. And yeah, you will yell, you will curse and you will laugh like a devil.Currently there are 3 gamemodes:1.) Death Race: All players fight for their survival while being hunted by a huge steamroller. The last survivor will get the most points and the first victim the least. This will go on for several rounds, until someone has reached a fixed number of score points.2.) King of the Hill: Only the leading player will gain one point per second. Whoever gains 50 points at first will win. You will respawn, if you die.3.) Race: 3 laps, first one will win. You will respawn, if you die.Pro:very easy and simple controls [keyboard: you navigate your vehicle left and right with your arrow keys/controller: you navigate your vehicle via holding the analog stick in the desired direction (some people don't like it, but I find it even better than the keyboard navigation)]nonstop actiongreat party game16 unique vehiclesvehicles are pretty balanced, all have their pros and consthe vehicle transformations are greatgood visual effectsfitting musicright amount and variety of PowerUps, not too less and not too manyfunny achievements and ingame medalsAI isn't as good as human players, but does a great job and provides fundouble fun with friends4 player local coopyou can join online multiplayer tournaments up to 8 players with your 4 local players!online multiplayer runs smoothly in generalyou can hop in already running matches and simply replace a botvote function for the next map and gamemodetons of evil attacks, evil laughter, WTF-moments and boom boomeven a failure can be so enjoyableNeutral:the visual effects can be excessive for sensible eyesplayer colour is defined by the order of connecting people [host is always red, the second connected player is always green and so on]Contra:you can easily loose the overview from time to time in 8 player matchesonly 3 gamemodes [2 more would be appropriate for more variety]only 6 (correct me if I'm wrong) maps [3-5 more would be appropriate for more variety]steam workshop support would be a great addition to solve the kinda low variety problemConclusion:BlazeRush can be a pretty good party game, if you have friends around. It's really easy to learn and it's so much fun to wreck someone in the right moment. Victory or failure doesn't matter that much, it's enough to hear your friend yelling, when you kick him/her off the the track, to conjure a evil smile into your face. You can even take your friends into online matches to double the fun. This game could be a straight 9 or 10 out of 10, but the small map and gamemode variety harms the overall great impression a lot, because it ruins longer gaming sessions, if you have to see the same tracks again and again (it's still fun though). What a pity! Nevertheless really recommendable.7/10----------------------~ Do you want to add something to the review or do you want to share your opinion? Feel free to make a comment.

												So Blazerush is really, really good.It's the best racing game I've ever played in my entire life. I actually enjoyed it more than Sonic All-Stars Racing Transformed.Basically you are racing through all these sweet-looking places, with 3-7 other cars, while frantically collecting weapon and boost powerups and mowing down everyone in your way.1 of the key mechanics of the game, that I've never thought I would enjoy, but I actually really do, is that you are never ever truly safe in front. Boost powerups would be constantly be dropped for the trailing racers, and if you fall back too much/get destroyed, you would be automatically be teleported forward a bit after a few seconds.So this translates into such a chaotic mess of a race in which you have to gun down the guy in front and evade that heat-seeking missile with quick zig-zags and body-block the car directly behind you and nudge the car beside you into the cliffs and oh ♥♥♥♥ you just run into your own bouncing saw it's crazy.Graphics are good. Physics are good. Hell, even the AI is good, knowing precisely when and where to shoot you so that you're chucked down into the abyss as you round that corner. I actually enjoy watching AI racing against each other, which is a first in racing games for me.The single-player career mode is quite meaty, in which you are introduced to new game modes/weapons/boosts stage by stage, which I clock at about 25 hours to finish due to the trophy system. Then there's the party mode, in which you can play multiplayer locally vs human/bots, or online. Unfortunately there are too few actual players at the moment, which is a shame, since I really enjoyed the local multiplayer.Anyway, if you end up getting it, the first thing you should do is go into Options and change the Video -> Camera tracks -> Local Players only. Trust me, it's better this way.TLDR: Blazerush > Sonic All-Stars Racing Transformed. Get it.

												Oh man, first Toybox Turbos in VR, then this? I'm blown away. First, I played this on a TV with my brothers, I gifted it to my brother who had brought his gaming laptop over Christmas. It was fantastic fun to walk through the single-player portion playing co-op. Sadly this mode is not available for online play, but multiplayer is basically the same thing as single when it comes to game modes and levels. This in contrast to Toybox Turbos which only has one mode in multiplayer.After the Christmas break, I've now played the game again in VR, now on my own Steam account so I do have more actual play time than reported. Right now I have the last level left in single player (so hard alone!), otherwise I've gotten through all levels with at least one cup, most with more cups. The progression is nice, you unlock new cars by getting score and new races by winning cups, which happens automatically when playing :)In multiplayer you have 3/4 of the vehicles from the start, so it works just fine to jump straight into that. The most extreme vehicles have to be unlocked by collecting score, which I did in single player... not sure if the score collected in multiplayer is actually counted towards unlocks... as I went to multiplayer first after finishing single :)So, on to the VR implementation and experience! This game performs perfectly on my 970, which it should I guess, it's a pretty new card. But I was able to run it at a full 75 Hz in VR, 2x supersampling, while recording in 60 fps. No issues. The entire game has been adapter to VR, when booting the game you are surrounded by video screens with a menu in front of you. When racing, the interface there also works very well in VR, not that I look at it very much but you have a map at the bottom and icons where expected, again I never have time to look at stuff I just turn my head and look around me if I want to get my bearings :)So, what have I found amazing in VR? The graphical fidelity is great, there are tons of particles through explosions, smoke and other effects, which looks great. The vehicles themselves has lots of detail, and it's very fun to just pause the game and look closer on the different machines. The large crusher in the death-race mode is especially interesting as you can read text on it and see walkways on top of the huge engine, just brilliant :)Fun stuff that happened, I got the camera begind the death-race crusher, and it felt like I got the thick exhaust smoke in my mouth :D Nutty! It's also pretty great when stuff fly at you, vehicles that are launched in the air and exploding into lots of tiny pieces... feels like being inside a small miniature firework show! Fantastic :DSome people has complained about the control method, which is a bit unique, you just aim in a direction and you drive there. If you've driven vehicles in Halo it's pretty much like that, just with a fixed camera. It's pretty key though as when you get shot at, your vehicle is all over the place! If you play with a keyboard you have normal steering, and I found it much harder to get going in the right direction after getting hit. Again, you might not find this intuitive, but I greatly enjoy it!Conclusion. If you like top-down racers or just fun party games, this is a title for you! If you want a great VR experience, this is that too! I would never have heard of this game, probably, unless they added VR! Lucky they did, because it's a great little game :D

												Update:As much as it pains me to do this, I've switched my recommendation to no. This game is no longer updated on Steam as it has become an Oculus Home exclusive. If you want the latest Rocket League-like update, it's not here. The icing on the cake is the leaderboards no longer work on Steam. I'm okay with system exclusives in general, but making something exclusive AFTER the fact and stopping support is shady. I won't be supporting the BlazeRush developers going forward. Is the game still good? Unfortunately, yes.Original:Easily one of the best games I've played. If you enjoyed R.C. Pro-Am or Rock n' Roll Racing back in the day this game is for you.  The controls are very intuitive: left joystick controls direction and A and X buttons control boosters and weapons.  The A.I. is spot on. There will be times you cannot believe a computer opponent will be so brilliant and then a few minutes later be surprised at something it does that's totally stupid.  The catch-up mechanic is nicely done. In these types of games it is usually programmed so that cars in the rear simply go faster in order to catch up, but in BlazeRush speed items are dropped in the back while weapons are dropped in the front. Always guaranteed to have some mayhem. Each car handles differently. The physics, while done in an arcade manner, are great. Expect to be knocked off the track lots... use a heavier car. There is a boss race! It is not a very challenging boss race once you find the pattern of avoiding his weapons, but a nice touch that gives the game a nice closer. Not that beating the boss makes you want to stop playing. There are plenty of cups to collect. Cups could be from getting placed in a race, earning so many points during a race, or killing so many opponents during a race, etc.. There are also public leaderboards which is always nice to see how you compare against others. As of this writing I am ranked 47th. :)

												Lemme just get the VR part out of the way.  Why sell the VR edition of this to be an Oculus exlusive...No Vive support if you buy it from here.  You could buy it from the Oculus Home store, or just play it on Revive.  Chances are though, seeing how scummy both this dev and Oculus are, you may be wasting your money for when they decide to close off Revive support.  You aren't missing much though, other than Oculus exlusive updates.  The game's okay; got some unbalanced decisions here and there(single player is bat♥♥♥♥♥♥dumb, and you HAVE to play it if you want to unlock everything).  From my few hours in game, I feel that depending on your play style, you will find one game mode that you find more enjoyable than the others, leaving the other 2 obsolete for when you have friends over.  Which, btw you will definitely need. Online is a absolute ghost town, no surprise there.Your choice of game modes are your regular old race, a king of the hill "stay in front" kind of race, and then Death Race where you get stomped out for being in last.  I personally find the death race to be the most enjoyable, but they all have their own issues.  Death race has an issue with a zoomed out camera depending on how far apart last and first place are.  Also, being the first one to die causes you to wait quite a bit till the rounds over, and trust me, it will happen a lot regardless of your skill... RNG plays a lot into this game, and you will have a lot of moments where you feel completely powerless.  But whatever, its a casual kart game so its easily overlooked.  The controls are a bit odd, but if you have ever played Kirby's Air Ride on the Gamecube, it plays just like the top ride view.  You point in the direction you want to go.  Not exactly a bad thing, but some people dislike that.  Its pretty clear from the screen-shots how it works, so keep it in mind if you choose to purchase.Track designs are pathetically generic, so much so that you will never quite recognize a track when you pick it.  You could just put the game on random track selection and it wouldn't make a difference really.  I'd honestly suggest it, makes the game move faster.  The tracks are all fairly easy to drive on regardless of what racer you pick though.  The racers themselves come in 3 general types, with varying stats between them within the 3 category's.  Honestly, I feel they are well balanced.  Its 100% a matter of your play style that will decide who you prefer to go with.  But, as said before, skill has very little effect on how likely you are to win; "balance" doesn't matter when you can just win randomly.  All vehicles have same max speed, and people will rubber band to the player in first.  The only stats that really matter are mobility, acceleration, and grip.So what of that RNG?  Well, considering the match will usually be filled out with AI, you will deal with being targeted in the free-for-all race style.. a LOT! This is what makes the single player campaign so frustrating.  Weapon pick-ups randomly fall from the sky, and you will occasionally have item drops completely avoid you.  You could be in last place in a death race and have no boosts to save you, or be in the middle of the pack and have a weapon dropped right on top of the guy behind you.  Physics for if you do get hit can be random; you could thrown entirely off the track, or barely budge at all.  Sometimes, a clean weapon hit can even throw the guy in front of you further into the lead.  You just never know.  I do need to mention, if you pick a hovercraft, you are pretty much guaranteed to be ♥♥♥♥ed up if you are hit by anything.  The added mobility and acceleration tend to not be worth the trade off.All in all, the game isn't exactly "bad".  The devs are pretty scummy for making this Oculus exclusive for VR support, and future updates are even tied specifically to that version.  For this, the desktop version is pretty much complete.  I don't think you will miss anything as far as game play is concerned.  There aren't too many games of this style for Steam, and the ones competing with this are mostly unoptimized, pathetic Android ports.  For $10, you probably will not find the value paying for this.  If you are a fan of local games, definitely worth it on sale, if only for a few hours of casual shared screen multi player.  Otherwise, for what your paying for, you could always get something better.  For a more skilful kart game, Sonic All Stars Racing Transformed would be good to look into if you haven't already got it.  You won't miss much for passing this game up.6/10: Good on a sale, but your money is better spent elsewhere.  Do not buy if RNG racing pisses you off.

												If you've got the people this is an amazing multiplayer experience. BlazeRush is a top-down racer with a few different game modes and plenty of pickups to fire at your opponents. There's a singleplayer campaign as well but you'll be finding most of your fun with the multiplayer options. All the racers share the same screen so you get pulled ahead (or destroyed) for falling behind. There's a standard lap race mode, a mode where the person in first the longest wins, and Death Race. The last mode is by far most fun I've had with this game. A giant machine chases all the racers around the track until everyone is eliminated. The person that survives longest nets the most points, and it starts right back up again until you reach a set number. This leads to plenty of hilarious moments as players struggle to stay far ahead with boosters or sabotage the competition with firepower. I'd say it's a definite buy. Online multiplayer's dead though so grab this with 2 or 3 friends.

												Blazerush is a top down, isometric racer, very similar to games like Rock n' Roll racing. It's got fairly solid gameplay for its type, about 4 different racing modes. Definitely feels like a micro machines game, in a really good way. Like any kart racer, the game can be chaotic, and when it doesn't go your way, it can be very frustrating. When it does go your way, you feel awesome pulling out of the explosions unscathed. The game has a good balance of this and a skillful player can get through most challenges, though sometimes it can feel as if your opponents are snatching all the powerups.The strength of this game is the death tractor races, which periodically eliminate the racer in last over several rounds. You can have a lot of fun boosting just out of the tractor's reach, and timing your shots perfectly to put an opponent behind you for the one moment the tractor appears. However, the other game modes were not fun for me. In one game mode, you must be the leader for 50 seconds. Seems fair, right? But for some reason, in this mode, it always seems like one AI is a lot harder than the others, and pulls ahead quickly. Then you can never reach him because your stuck behind the other ones who all seem out to stop you from winning. The only way to win this mode is to get ahead immediately and dodge all their shots. All in all, its a fun, short, kart racing game. If you're interested, this game will deliver for you.

												If Borderlands had a GILF fetish and had a baby with the old Micromachines games from the early-mid 90s, this would be the result.Very fun and simple racing game, with decent graphics, a kicking soundtrack that I can only describe as mixed techno/dubstep [probably the best part imo], a fun assortment of weapons and vehicles/characters to choose from that once all are unlocked create a great deal of chaos in the later levels, and some interesting tracks set on a few different fictional worlds. Its a fun mindless game [as with most racing games, dont expect much from the story] right up until the last level of the campaign.I only really had 2 issues with the game. One was that in some game modes, the game will port racers who are lagging behind, back into a closer position to the others. This was annoying as it felt very hand-holdy and quiet often it would port me straight over some pickups that otherwise would have won me a race or two. The other issue, was the final boss. At the end, the 'corporation' from the back-plot sends its 'president' to deal with you. he comes in a spaceship that looks like it was made by mercedes-bens, but armed by the military. He is almost impossible to beat - while most levels took only a few minutes to beat and were the kind of challenge that felt good to redo a few times until you beat it, I had to keep on reloading this mission tirelessly for the better part of an hour. [I'm not exactly one to give up easily, but I swear by the end of it I felt like throwing my controller across the room. XD] He has alot of health that you have to slowly widdle down, and if he knocks you off the track - which is extremely easy for him with his massive assortment of weapons that he spams you with - you loose immediatly. This might have been less of an issue if they gave you a couple of lives to beat him with, but you loose once and its game over. It was, for me, quiet frustrating, and didnt feel at all rewarding when I finally beat the game.All in all, its a super fun simple racer, probably better to play with friends then to play the campaign, really. I personally bought it through a BundleStars bundle, and dont feel its worth the full price on steam. But if you see it in a bundle or on sale, somewhere, I would highly recommend it for a night of pointless chaos.
